msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah - English translation of the Karaim text

ab.l:
Thus the creation of the skies
and of the earth and of all their hosts was finished.

And
on the seventh day God ended his own work which he had made and he ceased
|doing| on the seventh day all his work that he had made.

And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified
[it because in it] he ceased from |doing| all his work, which God had created.

These are the children of the heavens and [of the earth]
when they were created: In the day |when| Lord God |created| the earth [and the heavens],

And every tree of the plain: [before] it was [in the earth],
and every plant of the earth: before it grew, because the LORD God had [not caused]
the rain to rain on the earth, and there was no man [to work]
the ground,

But there went up a mist from [the earth]
and watered the whole face of the ground:

[And]
the Lord God created man [of] the dust of the [ground]
and breathed into his nose the breath of life, and [man] became a
living being.

And earlier the Lord [God] planted
a garden in Eden, and there he put the man whom [he had created].

And the Lord God caused every tree that is comely
to the sight and good for food to grow from the ground, and the tree of [life]
in the midst of the garden, and the tree of knowledge [of good]
and evil.

And a river went out of Eden to [water]
the garden, and from there it was parted, and became [four]
heads.

The name of one was Pison: it was the one that [encompasses]
the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.

And the gold of that land is good; there is ⸤pearl bed⸣ [and the]
onyx stone.

And the name of the second river was [Gihon]:
[it was] the one that encompasses the whole land of Cush.

And
the name of the third river was Tigris: it was the one that goes toward the east
of Assyria. And the fourth river was Euphrates.

And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden
to work it and to keep it.

And the Lord God commanded
the man, saying, ‘Of every tree of the garden:
you may surely eat their fruits.

But of the fruits
of the knowledge of good and evil: you shall not eat of it, because
in the day that you eat thereof you will have a debt of death’.

And the Lord God said,
‘It is not good for the man to be alone; I shall make
him a help corresponding to him.’

And
from the ground the Lord God created every wild animal of the earth, and every bird
of the skies, and brought them to the man to see what he would call
them. And whatever the man would call every living being, that was
its name.

And the man gave names to all livestock,
and to the bird of the skies, and to all the wild animals of the field.
But for the man: he did not find a help corresponding to him.

And the Lord God sent a deep sleep on the man
and he slept. And he took one of his ribs, and closed up
its place with flesh.

And the Lord God built
the rib that he had taken from the man, to be a woman, and he brought
her to the man.

And the man said, ‘This is now
living bone from my bones, and body [from my body]:
She shall be called “woman”, because it was taken from man.

[On account of this]
a man leaves his father and his mother and clings to his wife, [and]
they become one flesh.

And they were both
naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.

app.note: On every folio verso the last one or two lines contain one or more catchwords. They are omitted from the translation.

A mistranslation based on the confusion of Heb.
מִקֶּדֶם
‘eastward’ (Gen 2:8) with Heb.
מֻקְדָּם
‘former, early’. Repeated in a number of Karaim translations, observed already by Henderson (1826: 336). Translated correctly in V, R, and Kowalski (1929: 48).
